Fig. 1 FT-IR spectra of nTiZr–MS supports with different Ti/Zr molar ratios. Fig. 2 XRD patterns of Co/nTiZr–MS with different Ti/Zr molar ratios. (♦) Co3O4, (●) TiO2. Fig. 3 XPS spectra of Ti 2p, Si 2p, Zr 3d and Co 2p on the catalysts. (1) Co/MS; (2) Co/Ti–MS; (3) Co/3TiZr–MS; (4) Co/TiZr–MS; (5) Co/Ti3Zr–MS; (6) Co/Zr–MS. Fig. 4 (a) TPR and (b) H2-TPD profiles of Co/nTiZr–MS catalysts. Fig. 5 DRIFT spectra of CO adsorbed on Co/nTiZr–MS catalysts. Fig. 6 Temperature-programmed surface reaction (H2-TPSR) profiles of CO adsorbed on catalysts. (a) CH4, (b) CO2, (c) H2O. Effects of ZrO2 promoter on physic-chemical properties and activity of Co/TiO2–SiO2 Fischer–Tropsch catalysts Huatao Wu a b c Yong Yang a b ⁎ Haiyun Suo b Ming Qing b Lai Yan b Baoshan Wu a b Jian Xu b Hongwei Xiang a b ⁎ Yongwang Li a b a State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan 030001, Shanxi, People's Republic of China State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences Taiyuan Shanxi 030001 People's Republic of China b National Energy Research Center for Coal to Clean Fuels, Synfuels CHINA Co., Ltd., Huairou District, Beijing 101400, People's Republic of China National Energy Research Center for Coal to Clean Fuels, Synfuels CHINA Co., Ltd., Huairou District Beijing 101400 People's Republic of China c University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, People's Republic of China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 People's Republic of China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan 030001, Shanxi, People's Republic of China. Tel.: +86 10 69667699; fax: +86 10 69667653. Graphical abstract A series of Co-based catalysts containing 10wt.% cobalt for Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS) reaction were prepared by impregnation method, in which cobalt species were supported on mesoporous silica (abbreviated as MS) doped with TiO2, ZrO2 and TiO2–ZrO2 oxides as promoters. The incorporation of promoters was observed to have a profound impact on the physic-chemical and catalytic properties of catalysts. It was shown that the dispersion of cobalt species could be improved by the addition of TiO2, resulting in higher catalytic activity on Co/TiO2–MS catalyst (abbreviated as Co/Ti–MS). Meanwhile, the reducibility of cobalt species in Co/Ti–MS was apparently inhabited due to the strong Co–TiO2 interaction, while this effect was suppressed upon a small addition of ZrO2. With the further addition of ZrO2, the reducibility and dispersion of cobalt species were increased simultaneously, resulting in the improved activity. In addition, the H2 chemisorption was enhanced while CO adsorption was suppressed by the incorporation of ZrO2, which increased the H/C ratios on the surface of Co-based catalysts, and promoted the hydrogenation of surface carbon species. Consequently, methane selectivity was enhanced and heavy hydrocarbons selectivity was suppressed in FTS product distribution. The incorporation of promoters into Co/MS catalysts also improved the electron density of cobalt species due to the electron transfer from support to Co via the MOSi structure (M=Ti or Zr). The electron enrichment of cobalt species on Co/Ti–MS catalyst caused lower H/C ratio, resulting in higher selectivity to heavy hydrocarbons and lower selectivity to methane. Keywords Fischer–Tropsch synthesis Cobalt-based catalysts TiO2 ZrO2 Mesoporous silica 1 Introduction Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS) has being hotly investigated by lots of researchers in the world due to its ability to produce high quality middle distillates for motor application, so FTS is one of most efficient routes to convert coal, natural gas and biomass to liquid fuels free of S, N and other pollutants. In the development of FTS technology, one of the most important goals is to develop cobalt-based catalysts with high catalytic activity, reasonable selectivity to heavy hydrocarbons, low activity of water-gas shift (WGS) reaction and good FTS reaction stability [1,2]. It is well known that the nature of the carrier has a dramatic influence on the surface structure and activity of supported metal catalysts [3,4]. This is clearly illustrated by metals supported on partially reducible support or SMSI-type oxides [5,6]. The dispersion of the supported metal, however, may vary with the type of support used. Strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) may change the fraction of chemically non-reducible cobalt species during calcination and/or reduction steps. For example, although Co-based catalysts supported on Al2O3 exhibits well dispersed metallic cobalt cluster, low FTS activity is presented on these catalysts owing to the formation of inactive cobalt aluminates [7]. Similar phenomenon is observed on cobalt catalysts supported on the partially reducible support like TiO2. Well dispersed metallic cobalt clusters on Co/TiO2 catalyst are attributed to strong metal-support interaction, but TiO x (x <2) species reduced from TiO2 can be migrated from support to the surface of metallic cobalt and block the cobalt active sites, resulting in low catalytic activity [8]. The promoter incorporation can modulate the metal-support interaction and achieve high activity due to the ease of reduction of cobalt oxides and less formation of non-reducible species. Thus, commercially available inorganic supports, such as Al2O3 and TiO2 [9,10], have been modified with other oxides (La2O3, ZrO2, and MgO) as “promoters” to modulate the interaction between metal and support. In the case of Co/Al2O3 catalyst, incorporation oxides into catalyst, such as La2O3 and TiO2, can improve the reduction degree and catalytic activity through weakening metal-support interaction and suppressing the formation of non-reducible cobalt aluminate compound [11,12]. It is also found that the addition of zirconia can greatly influence the reduction behavior and catalytic activity of catalysts supported on TiO2 [13,14]. Lu et al. [13] found the low reduction of Pt/TiO2 catalysts owing to the blockage of metal Pt active sites by TiO x species from partially reduced TiO2, which suppressed catalytic activity in naphthalene hydrogenation reaction. However, the blockage of Pt by the migration of TiO x was apparently prevented by the addition of zirconia, resulting in high reduction degree and catalytic activity on Pt/TiO2-ZrO2. Ruppert et al. [14] also investigated that the effect of ZrO2 on crotonaldehyde hydrogenation reaction over Pt/ZrO2-TiO2 catalysts. The results indicated that the presence of ZrO2 in supports effectively inhibited the migration of TiO x species to Pt surface and improved its catalytic activity. Based on the above results, the addition of ZrO2 into TiO2 can greatly weaken the strong metal-TiO2 interaction and modify the structure of catalysts. However, low surface area and thermal stability of TiO2–ZrO2 is unfavorable to prepare catalyst as support. Thus, some researchers have been focused to stabilize ZrO2 and TiO2 on a silica support through the grafting technique, generating new supports that combine the larger surface area and thermal stability of silica, with the unique property of TiO2 and ZrO2 [15,16]. In the recent years, the use of ordered mesoporous silica such as MCM-41 and SBA-15 in heterogeneous catalysts has been attracting worldwide attention [17,18]. A tailored porous structure of mesoporous silica is beneficial for catalytic applications because it can effectively control the optimum active size of supported metal clusters or transition metal oxides. However, weak interaction between metal and mesoporous silica may cause poor dispersion of metal on catalysts. Thus, some metal oxides promoters, such as TiO2 and ZrO2, needed to be incorporated into the mesoporous silica to strengthen metal-support interaction and modify the structure of catalysts, which affect the metal dispersion and catalytic activity [15,16]. Recently, many papers were focused on the promotion of ZrO2 on structure, metal-support interaction and FTS reaction performance of Co/SiO2 catalysts [19–21]. It was accepted that that the incorporation of ZrO2 into Co/SiO2 catalysts could promoted the reducibility of cobalt species, moreover, increasing catalytic activity and heavy hydrocarbons selectivity were accompanied with the addition of ZrO2. Ali et al. [21] considered that the improved catalytic activity and heavy hydrocarbons selectivity were attributed to the formation of interface between metallic cobalt and ZrO2, which promoted the dissociation of CO on catalysts surface. However, there are limited researches about the preparation of cobalt catalysts supported on TiO2–ZrO2–SiO2 and promotion effects of ZrO2 on the structure and Fischer–Tropsch performance of catalysts. We expect that the addition of TiO2–ZrO2 oxide with different amount into the mesoporous silica would modulate the structure and the interaction between active metal Co and mesoporous silica on Co-based catalysts, which finally affect the FTS activity and hydrocarbon product distribution. In this study, a series of mixed oxides TiO2–ZrO2 with Ti/Zr molar ratios of 1:3, 1:1, 3:1 were incorporated into cobalt catalysts (10wt.% Co) supported on mesoporous silica to investigate the effect of ZrO2 promoter on catalysts structure and FTS performance. Multiple methods, such as N2 physisorption, XRD, H2-TPR, H2-TPD, LRS, FT-IR, H2-TPRS and XPS, were utilized to characterize these catalysts. Their FTS performance was tested in a fixed-bed reactor and correlated with their characterization results. 2 Experimental 2.1 Supports and catalysts preparation Mesoporous silica (MS) was synthesized according to the route reported in the literature [22], and the preparation process was detailed in the supporting information. Summarily, MO2–SiO2 supports (M=Ti, Zr and Ti–Zr) with weight ratio of MO2/SiO2 (25/100) were prepared with impregnation method. As for the preparation of nTiZr–MS supports, a proper amount of tetrabutyl orthotitanate (TBOT, 99.0%, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., China) and zirconium nitrate pentahydrate (99.0%, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., China) as precursor were dissolved in 60ml isopropanol (99.0%, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., China) under stirring in a beaker for 1h. Then 6g MS was added into the mixture under stirring, finally the beaker including above mixture was transported into a stainless steel autoclave. Equal volume isopropanol and 40ml deionized water were added into the interspace between beaker and polyethylene liner. The autoclave was transferred to the oven and kept at 333K for 72h, then the product was dried at 333K for 12h and calcined in air at 823K for 6h. The final product was defined as nTiO2–ZrO2–MS (abbreviated as nTiZr–MS), where n indicated the Ti/Zr molar ratios (n =3:1, 1:1 and 1:3). TiO2–MS (abbreviated as Ti–MS) and ZrO2–MS (abbreviated as Zr–MS) supports were synthesized using the same introducing manner described earlier in the nTiZr–MS preparation. Catalysts containing 10% Co (wt.%) were prepared with impregnation method. The above synthesized supports were impregnated with aqueous solution containing the desired amount of cobalt nitrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 99.0%, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., China), then the samples were dried at 333K for 12h and calcined at 723K in air for 4h. 2.2 Support and catalysts characterization 2.2.1 XRD XRD patterns for the calcined samples were recorded with an advanced D8 powder diffractometer (Bruker, Germany) with Cu Kα radiation (λ =0.154nm). The samples were scanned at small-angle range from 0.5° to 10° (2θ) and at large-angle range from 10° to 80° (2θ) with a step size of 0.02°, respectively. The crystallite phase was identified with the data of Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (JCPDS). 2.2.2 N2 physisorption analysis N2 physisorption experiment was conducted at 77K using a Surface Area and Porosimetry instrument (Micromeritics, Model 2420, USA). Prior to the experiment, the sample was degassed under vacuum at 363K for 1h and 623K for 6h. 2.2.3 Laser Raman spectroscopy (LRS) Laser Raman spectroscopy (LRS) of catalyst samples were recorded on a UV-vis Raman System 1000 (Renishaw, UK) using CCD as the detector and an argon-ion laser (k =514.4nm) as the ray source, that was set to an output power of 7mW. 2.2.4 CO adsorbed diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy CO adsorbed diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (CO-DRIFTS) experiment was also performed with a Vertex 70 FT-IR spectrometer. The catalyst sample (15mg) was pretreated in pure hydrogen (20ml/min) for 2h at 673K, and then the temperature fell to 298K under flowing argon (20ml/min) to prevent the adsorption of weakly-bound species. The spectra were obtained at room temperature after the exposure of catalyst to CO at a rate 30ml/min for 1h, followed by sweeping in argon for 0.5h. The spectra of all samples were presented by subtracting the background spectrum. 2.2.5 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) XPS was recorded on a VG Mutilab 2000 spectrometer (Bruker, Germany) using an Al Kα (hν =1486.7eV) as X-ray source. The binding energies were corrected for charge shifts, with the use of the C 1s=285eV peaks as reference. The pressure of the sample chamber was less than 2×10−8 Pa. 2.2.6 Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) H2-TPR was performed in a dynamic analyzer (Micromeritics, Model 2920, USA). Prior to the H2-TPR measurement, the catalyst sample (150mg) was first flushed with Ar (30ml/min) at 423K for 1h, and then cooled down to 323K. Subsequently, 5% H2/95% Ar (v/v) with a flow rate of 50ml/min was flown through the catalyst while the temperature was increased to 1173K at a linear ramp rate of 10K/min. The outlet gas concentration was monitored by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 2.3 Hydrogen chemisorption H2 chemisorption was also performed using Micromeritics instrument (Model 2920, USA). Prior to the adsorption, the catalysts (250mg) were pre-treated in flowing He (50ml/min) at 393K for 1h. Afterward, the samples were reduced in pure hydrogen (50ml/min) at 673K for 12h and then cooled down to 323K. Subsequently, flowing argon (30ml/min) was introduced to remove the adsorption of weakly bound physisorbed species, and then H2 pluses were injected until the eluted peak area of consecutive pluses was constant. Finally, the temperature slowly increased to 1173K at a linear ramp rate of 10K/min. The variation of the outlet gas concentration was monitored by TCD. Isopropyl alcohol gel was used as a cold trap to remove the water formed during the test. It was assumed that the adsorption atom stoichiometry is H:Co=1:1. The corrected dispersion (D Corr %) with reduction degree was calculated as follows [23]: D C o r r % = Number of Co 0 atoms on surface Total number of Co atoms × Fractional degree of reduction × 100 % The corrected cobalt particles size (dp) was calculated from the cobalt dispersion by assuming spherical, uniform cobalt metal particles with site density of 14.6atoms/nm2. Thus, the cobalt metal particles size (dp) was calculated by the following formula, dp=96/D Corr % [23]. 2.3.1 Temperature-programmed surface reaction (H2-TPSR) The H2-TPSR analysis was performed in a self-assembly quartz micro-reactor at atmospheric pressure. The catalyst sample (200mg) was previously reduced with pure hydrogen (40ml/min) at 673K for 12h, and then cooled down to 298K. Then the sample was saturated adsorption by introduced CO (20ml/min) and the weakly bound physisorbed CO was removed by argon (30ml/min). The temperature was increased to 1173K at a linear ramp rate of 10K/min. The concentration of outlet gas was determined by mass spectrometry (Themostar, Pfeiffer, Germany). 2.4 Catalysts tests Fischer–Tropsch synthesis was performed in a stainless steel fixed-bed reactor with inner diameter of 12mm. The 2.5g of cobalt-based catalyst sample (20–40 mesh) was loaded into the reactor and the remaining volume of the reactor tube was filled with quartz granules in a size range of 20–40 mesh. All catalysts were reduced with H2 (space velocity of 1000L/kgcat/h) at 673K, 0.10MPa for 12h. The reaction conditions were maintained at 493K and 503K, P =2.0MPa, space velocity (SV)=2000L/kgcat/h, and H2/CO=2.0. A detailed description of the reactor and product analysis system has been provided elsewhere [24]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural and structural characterization of supports The small-angle XRD patterns of MS and nTiZr–MS supports with different Ti/Zr molar ratios were shown in Fig. S1 (see supporting information). A broad diffraction peak at about 2θ =2° was observed on mesoporous silica and doped supports, moreover the peak intensity decreased after incorporating TiO2 and ZrO2 oxides. The presence of diffraction peaks at about 2θ =2° indicated mesoporous structure of supports, meanwhile a decrease in the intensity of diffraction peaks on nTiZr–MS supports showed that the mesoporous structure of MS support was partially destroyed by the addition of oxides. The large-angle XRD patterns of nTiZr–MS supports with different Ti/Zr molar ratios were shown in Fig. S1b. The diffraction peaks at 2θ =25°, 38°, 48°, 53°, 55° and 63° on supports with high Ti loading, such as Ti–MS and 3TiZr–MS, were assigned to bulk anatase titania, indicating the agglomeration of titania on samples. With the decreasing of Ti loading, the diffraction peaks corresponding to TiO2 disappeared, which is attributed to highly dispersed TiO2 at low Ti loading. The absence of ZrO2 diffraction peaks in all samples showed that incorporated ZrO2 was amorphous or too small to be detected by XRD. The results of N2 physisorption analysis of all samples were shown in Table S1 and Fig. S2 (see supporting information). N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of all supports (Fig. S2a) exhibited a type-IV isotherm curve with an H2 type hysteresis loop, which is characteristic of the mesoporous structure. Meanwhile, all supports demonstrated the characteristic of dual pore size distribution (Fig. S2b). One is centered at ∼3nm and the other at ∼50nm. The textural properties of supports and Co-based catalysts are listed in Table S1. As can be seen, in addition to relatively high surface area (892m2/g), mesopore (3.1nm) and macropore (53.2nm) coexisted in parent MS support. Comparing with MS support, a progressive decrease in surface area and pore volume was observed on nTiZr–MS catalysts as a function of the oxides loading, especially for Ti–MS and Zr–MS. The decreased pore size and pore volume on nTiZr–MS supports were attributed to the plugged pores by incorporated oxides and this effect was more pronounced in Ti–MS and Zr–MS supports, indicating more incorporated oxides into the pore of the supports doped with single oxide in contrast to the supports with coexistence of TiO2–TiO2 binary oxides. Moreover, a larger extent of decrease in macropore than that of mesopore, indicating that incorporated oxides preferred to entering macropore. The FT-IR spectra of all supports were shown in Fig. 1 . Three IR adsorption peaks at 1080cm−1, 960cm−1 and 800cm−1 were found in all samples. The bands at 1080cm−1 and 800cm−1 corresponded to the typical asymmetric stretching and symmetric stretching vibrations of SiOSi of silica network, respectively. It should be noted that the band at 960cm−1 on MS support was usually assigned to SiOH stretching vibration. Similar band on Ti–MS support was attributed to the SiOTi stretching vibrations [25], indicating that Ti species could be incorporated into the silica network of MS. Meanwhile the intensity of the band at 960cm−1 on nTiZr–MS supports decreased with the decreasing TiO2 content. Compare with MS support, the band at 1080cm−1 corresponding to SiOSi of nTiZr–MS supports shifted toward to lower wavenumber as the ZrO2 content increased, and its intensity was also decreased. Zhao et al. [26] and Tyagi et al. [27] also found the red shift in the SiOSi band on ZrO2–SiO2 oxides with the increase of ZrO2 content and explained the reason for this shift due to the replacement of Si ions in the framework by Zr ions. In present work, the red shift of SiOSi band on nTiZr–MS supports with the increasing ZrO2 content indicated the incorporation of Zr species into the silica framework of nTiZr–MS supports. 3.2 Textural and structural characterization of catalysts The XRD patterns of Co/nTiZr–MS catalysts with different Ti/Zr molar ratios were shown in Fig. 2 . The diffraction peaks at 31.4°, 36.9°, 45.0°, 59.5° and 65.5° were assigned to cubic phase Co3O4 (JCPDS 65-3103), which existed on all catalysts. Meanwhile the size data of the Co3O4 crystallites were listed in Table S1. As can be seen, much lower intensity of Co3O4 diffraction peak was observed on Co/Ti–MS catalyst compared to Co/MS catalyst. However, the intensity of Co3O4 diffraction peak obviously increased after incorporating a small amount of zirconia, and then decreased with the increasing addition of zirconia. Owing to weak metal-support interaction, poor dispersion of metal or metal oxides species is observed on catalysts supported on silica. Thus, strong diffraction peaks of Co3O4 were observed on Co/MS catalyst, indicating low dispersion of Co3O4 (18.5nm). Much lower intensity of diffraction peaks on Co/Ti–MS catalyst suggested well dispersed Co3O4 particles after introducing TiO2 into MS support, indicating that the addition of TiO2 could help to improve the dispersion of Co3O4 (14.1nm). With the addition of ZrO2, the Co3O4 particle size increased firstly and reached a maximum value (20.5nm) at Co/3TiZr–MS catalyst, and then decreased with the increasing addition of ZrO2. Table S1 showed the results of N2 physisorption analysis for all catalysts. As can be seen, the surface area, pore volume and average pore size of all catalysts synchronously decreased after introducing cobalt species, especially for Co/Ti–MS catalyst, which were attributed to plugged silica pore with cobalt oxide crystallites. Much lower pore volume and pore size on Co/Ti–MS catalyst indicated more cobalt species into the pore interior. However, mesoporous (∼3nm) structure was still obtained on these catalysts, suggesting that the pores were not heavily blocked by cobalt species. The Laser Raman spectra (LRS) of all catalysts were illustrated in Fig. S3 (see supporting information). The bands located at 691, 620, 523, 485 and 194cm−1 on cobalt-based catalysts corresponded to the Raman-active modes of Co3O4 with the symmetries of A1g, F2g, Eg [28]. The bands at 520 and 145cm−1 on Co/Ti–MS and Co/3TiZr–MS catalysts were assigned to the modes of anatase titania with the symmetries of A1g and Eg respectively. However, the absence of bands at 520 and 145cm−1 on catalysts with low TiO2 content indicated better dispersion of TiO2 on catalysts, which was in agreement with the results of XRD. Meanwhile, no bands about ZrO2 were observed on all catalysts. It was also found the shift of band at 693cm−1 corresponding to Co3O4 after incorporating oxides. An obvious downward shift of Co3O4 band was observed on Co/Ti–MS catalysts in contrast to Co/MS catalyst. Upon a small addition of ZrO2 into Co/Ti–MS catalyst, the Co3O4 band upward shifted at first, and then oppositely shifted to low wavenumber with the further addition of ZrO2. The shift of Raman peak is usually related with the sample particles size. Namely, the Raman peak shifts to lower wavenumber and gets progressively broader as the particles size gets smaller [29]. Comparing with Co/MS catalyst, a downward shift of Co3O4 Raman peak on Co/Ti–MS catalyst indicated that the addition of TiO2 could help to improve the dispersion of Co3O4. While an opposite change trend was observed on Co/3TiZr–MS catalyst, suggesting that the dispersion of cobalt oxides was suppressed by a small addition of ZrO2. Subsequently, the decreasing Co3O4 particle size was accompanied with the further addition of zirconia. These results are in agreement with the result of XRD characterization. 3.3 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) The XPS spectra of Ti2p, Si2p, Zr3d and Co2p for all catalysts were shown in Fig. 3a–d. The binding energy at 103.5eV on Co/MS was assigned to Si2p, which approximately equaled to the binding energy of pure SiO2 (103.5eV). As shown in Fig. 3a, the core level peak of Ti2p shifted to higher binding energy with the increase of TiO2 content; while an opposite change trend was observed on Si2p. Moreover, the Zr3d binding energy in ZrO2-containing catalysts shifted to higher value with respect to ZrO2 content. It is well known that the binding energy of atom is affected by the variation of the electron density around the central atom, namely, the greater the electron density of the adjacent atoms, the lower the binding energy of the central atoms [24]. An increase in binding energy of Ti2p and Zr3d was presented on Co/nTiZr–MS with the increase of TiO2 and ZrO2 content, while the opposite variation trend was observed on Si2p core-level spectra. This binding-energy shift was attributed to the formation of MOSi linkage (M=Ti, Zr) in the silica network [30,31]. Owing to higher electronegativity of Si atom (1.90) than that of Ti (1.54) and Zr (1.33), partial electrons could transform from metal atom M (M=Ti, Zr) to Si through MOSi structure, resulting in an electron-rich state of SiO group and an electron-deficient state of Ti and Zr species. Consequently, the binding energy of Si2p decreased, while the Ti2p and Zr3d binding energy increased. Implied from Co2p photoelectron peak, the binding energies located at ∼780eV and ∼795eV were assigned to the Co2p3/2 and Co2p1/2 respectively. The characteristic Co2p3/2 peak at around 780eV was assigned to the fully oxidized Co3O4 clusters denoted as Co(I) [32], and the satellite peaks at higher binding energy around 785eV attributed to the localized amorphous-phase Co2+ species denoted as Co(II) [33]. The presence of satellite peak at ∼785eV was usually related with the non-reducible cobalt species by forming a strong metal-support interaction, such as cobalt aluminate and cobalt silicate [34]. The surface composition of samples was listed in Table S2. As can be seen, an increase in Co(II)/Co(I) and Co/(Ti+Zr+Si) ratios were observed on Co/Ti–MS catalysts compared to Co/MS catalysts. While Co(II)/Co(I) and Co/(Ti+Zr+Si) ratios were decreased obviously upon a small addition of zirconia and reached a minimum value on Co/3TiZr–MS catalyst, then increased with the further addition of ZrO2. Lower Co(II)/Co(I) ratio on Co/MS catalyst suggested that less non-reducible cobalt species were formed due to weak Co–SiO2 interaction. Contrarily, the Co(II)/Co(I) ratio increased to a higher value on Co/Ti–MS catalyst, indicating that larger amount of non-reducible cobalt species were formed on catalysts. It is now accepted that lower reduction degree on Co/TiO2 catalyst is attributed to strong Co–TiO2 interaction. As confirmed in XRD and LRS analysis, obvious agglomeration of TiO2 was observed on Co/Ti–MS catalyst, which could strength the interaction between cobalt and support. Therefore, higher cobalt dispersion and Co(II)/Co(I) ratio were observed on Co/Ti–MS catalyst. However, this effect was obviously weakened by a small addition of ZrO2, resulting in lower cobalt dispersion and Co(II)/Co(I) ratio on Co/3TiZr–MS catalyst. With the further addition of ZrO2, the increasing Co(II)/Co(I) and Co/(Ti+Zr+Si) ratio suggested the strengthened interaction between cobalt and support by the incorporation of ZrO2. 3.4 H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) The reducibility of cobalt-based catalysts was studied by H2-TPR (see Fig. 4 a and Table 1 ). As can be seen, two reduction peaks were observed at different regions, i.e., a shoulder peak centered at 573K (denoted as I) and one main peak at around 600–650K (denoted as II). It is well known that the peaks at 500–700K are typically assigned to the two-step reduction of Co3O4 (Co3O4 →CoO and CoO→Co0), and H2 consumption ratio for these two-step reduction is 1:3 [34]. The high reduction peak (>700K) usually attributed to the reducibility of non-reducible cobalt species. As illustrated in Fig. 4a, there was no high temperature reduction peak corresponding to non-reducible cobalt species on Co/MS catalyst, except for the reduction peaks at 593K and 623K. After incorporating TiO2 into Co/MS catalyst, the reduction peaks shifted to lower temperature (584K and 612K). Moreover a new broad peak appeared at 700–800K was also observed on Co/Ti–MS catalyst. It was also found that the addition of zirconia greatly influenced the reduction behavior of Co/nTiZr–MS catalysts. Upon a small addition of ZrO2, an obvious decrease in the intensity of reduction peak centered at high temperature (750K) was observed on Co/3TiZr–MS catalyst. With the further addition of zirconia, the reduction peaks of Co/nTiZr–MS catalysts shifted to high temperature firstly when the ZrO2 content up to ZrO2/TiO2 =1, and then oppositely shifted to low temperature. The results of H2-TPR indicated that the large addition of TiO2 would suppress the reducibility of catalyst, while the reduction degree was obviously improved by a small addition of ZrO2. The H2 consumption of all catalysts within the temperature range 500–700K was listed in Table S3. Deconvolution of the reduction peaks centered at 600K for Co/MS catalyst resulted in a peak II/peak I area ratio of 3.17, in agreement with the theoretical value of 3. Meanwhile the sum of H2 consumption for peak I and peak II (2.22mmol H2/gcat) was consistent with the theoretical H2 consumption of Co3O4 to Co0 (2.26mmol H2/gcat), indicating almost complete reduction of cobalt species on Co/MS catalyst. While an obvious decrease in peak II/peak I (1.88) and total H2 consumption (1.50mmol H2/gcat) was observed on Co/Ti–MS catalyst. In contrast, the peak II/peak I and total H2 consumption were increased by a small addition of ZrO2, reaching a maximum value for Co/3TiZr–MS catalyst, and then slightly decreased on Co/nTiZr–MS catalysts with further increasing ZrO2 content. This phenomenon is consistent with the other studies [37,38]. O'Shea et al. [35] thought that the formation of TiO x (x <2) on Co/TiO2 from the partial reduction of TiO2 would migrate to the surface of Co and encapsulate metal Co. Moreover, the reduced cobalt species could react with titanium-oxygen of TiO x and form mixed oxides, resulting in a low reducibility of cobalt species. This phenomenon was also observed in Pt/TiO2 samples by Gai et al. [36]. The migration of TiO x into metal surface could be suppressed by the addition of ZrO2 [13,14]. In present work, higher reduction degree on Co/MS catalyst indicated that there is weak interaction between cobalt and support. In contrast, lower reduction degree on Co/Ti–MS catalyst was probably attributed to the blockage of cobalt species by the TiO x from the partial reduction of TiO2, while this effect was weakened by a small addition of ZrO2, resulting in higher reducibility of cobalt species on Co/3TiZr–MS catalyst. With the further addition of ZrO2, the interaction between cobalt and support was strengthened by the incorporation of ZrO2, which suppressed the reduction of cobalt species. It was also found that similar H2 consumption of peak I (∼0.52mmol H2/gcat) for all catalysts approximately equaled to theoretical value of Co3O4 to CoO (0.56mmol H2/gcat), indicating that the first step reduction of cobalt species was not almost affected by the promoters. While the different H2 consumption of peak II suggested that the promoter effect was more pronounced on the second step reduction (CoO to Co0) of cobalt species. This should be due to the existence of a strong cobalt-support interaction, which make it difficult for the CoO reduction to occur in the presence of TiO2 or ZrO2. Thus, the reduction process of CoO to Co0 was accompanied with the formation of non-reducible cobalt species. This result is in agreement with previous research [37]. 3.5 H2-temperature programmed desorption (H2-TPD) H2-TPD was used to investigate the effect of promoters on the H2 adsorption behavior of cobalt-based catalysts (Fig. 4b). As can be seen, H2 desorption occurred at three temperature ranges. In addition to a lower temperature peak at 353K (α), two H2 desorption peaks were observed at 600K (β) and 800K (γ) respectively. For the Co/MS catalyst, three peaks located at 353K and 820K respectively, accompanied by a weak peak at around 650K. Similar H2 adsorption curves were observed on Co/Ti–MS catalyst. It is different that the adsorption peak area was increased by the incorporation of TiO2. Contrarily, the lower temperature range was obviously decreased upon a small addition of ZrO2. With the further addition of ZrO2, the increasing area of lower temperature peak was accompanied with the disappearance of high temperature adsorption peak. The H2 uptakes (<673K) of all catalysts were listed in Table 1. In fact, the H2 adsorption capacity is closely related with the amount of metallic cobalt active sites, which depends on the reducibility and dispersion of cobalt species. In present work, the incorporation of TiO2 into Co/MS catalysts caused a loss in metallic cobalt sites due to the lower reduction degree and blockage of metallic cobalt by TiO x (x <2) species, simultaneously the dispersion and reduction at low temperature of the cobalt species were also improved by addition of TiO2. Thus, comparing with Co/MS catalyst, higher H2 uptake over Co/Ti–MS catalyst was attributed to well-dispersed cobalt metal particles, which provided more active sites to absorb more H2 molecules. In contrast, although higher reduction degree presented on Co/MS and Co/3TiZr–MS catalysts, poor dispersion of cobalt species is not conducive to the adsorption of H2 molecule, resulting in lower H2 uptake on these catalysts. With the further addition of ZrO2, the enhanced H2 uptake was attributed to proper reduction and dispersion of cobalt species at high ZrO2 loading, especially for Co/Zr–MS catalyst. 3.6 CO-DRIFTS CO-DIRFTS was usually applied to indentify the chemical and electronic environment of cobalt species. The spectra of CO adsorbed on the surface of cobalt-based catalysts after reduction were illustrated in Fig. 5 . The bands located at 1870 and 1790cm−1 corresponding to the stretching vibrations of bridged-bonded CO on cobalt sites, can be observed for all catalysts. Comparing with Co/MS catalyst, higher intensity of bands on Co/nTiZr–MS catalysts indicated that CO adsorption was improved by the incorporation of promoters. It was also found that the greatly enhanced intensity of IR peaks was observed on Co/Ti–MS catalysts, and then gradually decreased with the increase of ZrO2 content, except for Co/TiZr–MS catalyst. In addition, a red shift of CO adsorption peak was observed on the doped catalysts. The formation of bridged bond CO on cobalt metal sites can be explained by the σ-Π binding model [38]. When CO was adsorbed on metal clusters, electron transfer occurred from the d-orbital of metal to antibonding π* orbital of CO [39]. High electron density on metal sites caused high back donating from metal to the CO π* orbital. This back donating weakened the CO bond of CO adsorbed on metal, resulting in a red shift of the CO stretching frequency [40]. As shown in Fig. 5, the red shift for the adsorbed CO on Co/nTiZr–MS catalysts indicated that CO molecules accepted additional electrons from cobalt metal. It should be noted that the electron density of metal is closely related with the electronic property of atoms or groups surrounded [41,42]. Ramaker et al. [41] proposed that the composition of the support greatly affected the electronic property of support oxygen around Pt metal particles, which could change the electron density of Pt through electron transfer with oxygen atom. Visser et al. [42] also found that the addition of alkali or earth alkali metal ions into Pt/H-Y catalysts could improve the electron density of support oxygen atoms around Pt metal particles, resulting in the electron-rich state of Pt due to electron transfer from oxygen atom. Combing results of XPS and FT-IR analysis, it is reasonable that the formation of MOSi (M=Ti and Zr) bond on Co/nTiZr–MS catalysts lead to the formation of high electron-rich SiO group. Thus the red shift of the adsorbed CO on the Co/nTiZr–MS catalysts may be attributed to the electron transfer from electron-rich SiO group to metallic cobalt. Meanwhile, high electron density of metallic cobalt also weakened the CO bond of adsorbed CO and conduced to the dissociation of CO on catalysts. The results of CO-DRIFTS indicated that the incorporated promoters not only improved the CO adsorption capacity, but also changed the electronic property of metallic cobalt on Co/nTiZr–MS catalysts. 3.7 Temperature programmed surface reaction (H2-TPSR) Fig. 6 presented the influence of promoters on the H2-TPSR spectra of adsorbed CO on the Co/nTiZr–MS catalysts. As insulated in Fig. 6a, the promoted cobalt-based catalysts displayed stronger peak intensity for methane than that of Co/MS catalyst, especially for Co/Ti–MS catalyst, suggesting that the dissociation and hydrogenation of CO on catalysts were facilitated by promoters. It was also found that different temperature of methane formation presented on promoted catalysts and fellow the order: Co/Ti–MS<Co/Zr–MS<Co/Ti3Zr–MS<Co/TiZr–MS<Co/3TiZr–MS. Lower formation temperature of methane for catalysts implied stronger ability to dissociate CO. In fact, the dissociation of CO adsorbed on cobalt catalyst is influenced by the electronic property of cobalt species. The electron-rich state of cobalt species would strengthen the back donating from metal to the CO π* orbital, and then weaken the CO bond of CO adsorbed on metal. As confirmed in CO-DRIFTS, a red-shift of CO adsorbed on promoted cobalt-based catalysts indicated an electron enrichment of Co species on catalysts, moreover this phenomenon was more pronounced on Co/Zr–MS catalyst. Meanwhile, strong CO adsorption peak intensity on Co/Ti–MS catalyst meant more dissociated CO molecules on the surface of catalysts. Thus, lower formation temperature of methane was observed on doped catalysts, especially for Co/Ti–MS and Co/Zr–MS. It should be noted that the CH4 formation temperature on TPSR spectra was reported to correspond closely to the catalytic activity of catalysts [43]. Namely, CH4 formation temperature is lower, the higher catalytic activity. Comparing with Co/MS, lower CH4 formation temperature on doped catalysts, moreover, the methane formation temperature shifted to lower with the increase of promoter content. It can be assumed that higher catalytic activity on promoted catalysts, especially for Co/Ti–MS and Co/Zr–MS catalysts. Fig. 6b and c displayed the formation of CO2 and H2O on various cobalt-based catalysts during H2-TPSR reaction, respectively. As shown in Fig. 6b, the CO2 formation temperature fellow the order: Co/Ti3Zr–MS<Co/TiZr–MS<Co/Ti–MS<Co/Zr–MS<Co/3TiZr–MS<Co/MS. In general, the routes of CO2 formation during H2-TPSR reaction are mainly derived from CO disproportionation reaction, water gas shift reaction and CO oxidation reaction [44]. Comparing with the H2O formation temperature illustrated in Fig. 6c, it is obvious that the peak temperature of CO2 on catalysts is lower than that of H2O, suggesting that CO2 is not only produced from water gas shift reaction. In fact, the CO adsorbed on metal surface may react with oxygen associated with the metal oxide in catalysts to produce CO2 [45]. Considering low reduction degree of Co/TiZr–MS, Co/Ti3Zr–MS and Co/Ti–MS, the lower CO2 formation temperature on above-mentioned catalysts was probably attributed to the oxidation of CO on some oxidic metal species correlated with the unreduced cobalt oxides. 3.8 Fischer–Tropsch synthesis tests The FTS performance of cobalt-based catalysts with different Ti/Zr molar ratio were tested in a fixed bed reactor at 493 and 503K under the pressure of 2.0MPa, H2/CO=2 and GHSV=2000L/kgcat/h. The CO conversion was usually used as a measure of FTS activity. As illustrated in Table 2 , higher CO conversion was observed on doped catalysts than that of Co/MS. In the case of Co/nTiZr–MS catalysts, CO conversion increased from 37.6% to 81.0% when TiO2 was introduced into Co/MS catalyst. Contrarily, CO conversion decreased rapidly upon a small addition of ZrO2 into Co/Ti–MS catalyst, then increased with the further addition of ZrO2. It was generally accepted that the FTS performance of a cobalt catalysts was mainly governed by reducibility and dispersion of cobalt species, both of which were considered to be related to the nature of the support employed. Although higher reduction degree observed on Co/MS and Co/3TiZr–MS catalysts in contrast to other catalysts, poor dispersion of cobalt species to a certain extent suppressed the CO conversion. Excluding Co/3TiZr–MS catalyst, the dispersion of cobalt species on doped catalysts was improved by the incorporation of promoters, especially for Co/Ti–MS and Co/Zr–MS, resulting in higher FTS activity. The variation of CO conversion with the time on the stream (TOS) at 493K and 503K respectively are shown in Fig. 7a. As can be seen, an obvious drop in CO conversion was observed with time on stream, indicating partial deactivation of catalysts. The cobalt-based catalysts supported on mesoporous silica usually display poor stability due to the destruction of mesoporous structure under high temperature and high steam pressure in FTS reaction process [46]. Thus, an obvious drop in CO conversion was also observed on Co/MS catalyst, especially at high temperature (503K). Similar deactivation phenomenon was observed on catalysts doped with promoters. In the case of Co/Ti–MS catalyst, the CO conversion rapidly decreased from 96.8% initial activity to 85.9% after 100h at 503K. The deactivation of catalysts was generally ascribed to the decrease in the amount of the metallic cobalt active sites resulting from sintering and re-oxidation of the cobalt nanoparticles during the FTS reaction. In the present work, the XRD patterns of reduced and used catalysts were applied to indentify the reasons for deactivation of catalysts (see Fig S4). As shown in Fig. S4a, the diffraction peaks 2θ =44.4° and 51.7° were attributed to metallic cobalt, meanwhile there was no evidence of cobalt oxides was observed on reduced catalysts. Comparing with reduced catalysts, in addition to the diffraction corresponding to metallic cobalt, weak diffraction peaks of CoO (2θ =36.5° and 42.3°) were also detected by XRD on all used catalysts, suggesting the occurrence of metallic cobalt re-oxidation by oxidizing substances like water during the reaction process. These effects were more apparent on Co/MS catalyst. The size of cobalt metal particles calculated by Scherrer equation was listed in Table 1. As can be seen, there is an increase in metallic cobalt particles size for these used catalysts in contrast to that of their reduced catalysts, except for Co/MS catalyst, indicating sintering of cobalt metal particles as the reaction proceeded. Comparing phase change of cobalt species during reaction, the re-oxidation of metallic cobalt was attributed to the deactivation of Co/MS catalyst. In general, sintering and re-oxidation of metallic cobalt seemed to be responsible for the deactivation of Co/nTiZr–MS catalysts particularly during the initial hours of FTS reaction. The water produced from Fischer–Tropsch synthesis reaction greatly influenced the stability of cobalt-based catalysts, especially for catalysts supported on mesoporous silica. The metallic cobalt of catalysts could be oxidized into inactive cobalt oxides, resulting in a decrease in FTS reaction activity. It was accepted that mesoporous silica was not stable in the hydrothermal environment. Thus, the cobalt-based catalysts supported on mesoporous silica usually displayed poor catalysts stability due to the structure destruction of mesoporous silica considering high steam pressure and high temperature during FTS reaction. Considering the reviewer's suggestion, we have investigated the textural property of Co/nTiZr–MS catalysts before and after reaction to study the effect of water producing from FTS reaction on the mesoporous structure. The textural property of fresh catalysts and used catalysts was shown in Fig. S5 and Table S4. Considering the reviewer's suggestion, we have investigated the textural property of Co/nTiZr–MS catalysts before and after reaction to study the effect of water producing from FTS reaction on the mesoporous structure. Comparing with fresh catalysts, there was an obvious decrease in surface area and pore volume observed on used catalysts (seeing Table S4). Lower surface area of used catalysts would suppress the dispersion of cobalt species and lead to agglomeration of metallic cobalt particles, which was in agreement with the results of XRD. As can be seen from Fig. S5, there was also an apparent drop in the pore size of catalysts after the FTS reaction. It should be noted that the mesoporous structure of Co/Ti–MS and Co/Zr–MS catalysts were largely destroyed. As previously mentioned, mesoporous silica was not stable in the hydrothermal environment. Thus, the mesoporous structure of Co/nTiZr–MS catalysts would be destroyed in the high steam pressure and high temperature during FTS reaction. As for Co/Ti–MS and Co/Zr–MS catalysts, higher FTS activity would produce high water steam pressure, which accelerated to the destruction of mesoporous silica, resulted in an obvious activity drop in initial hours. Thus, the destruction effects of water on mesoporous structure were more apparent on Co/Ti–MS and Co/Zr–MS catalysts. In summary, the mesoporous structure of Co/nTiZr–MS catalysts was destroyed by the water produced from FTS reaction, which decreased surface area and cobalt species dispersion, resulting in poor catalysts stability. The hydrocarbon product distribution of these cobalt-based catalysts was shown in Table 2 and Fig. 7. As can be seen, the selectivity to gaseous light hydrocarbons (methane and C2-C4) was enhanced, whereas that to heavy hydrocarbons (C5 +) and the ratio of olefin to paraffin (C2–4 =/C2–4 0, O/P) was suppressed by the addition of ZrO2. Generally FTS product selectivity is related with the H/C ratio on the surface of catalysts [47,48]. It was reported that local increase of the H/C ratio near the surface Co0 sites would favor hydrogenation of the adsorbed carbon species to light hydrocarbons. In our present work, H2-TPD and CO-DRIFTS results indicated that H2 and CO adsorption were simultaneously enhanced by the incorporation of TiO2, while the addition of ZrO2 suppressed the CO adsorption but improved the H2 adsorption. This resulted in a high H/C ratio on the surface of Co/nTiZr–MS catalysts and a high hydrogenation capability. As confirmed in CO-DRIFTS, a red shift of CO adsorbed on Co/Ti–MS on catalyst implied a rich-electron state of cobalt species. The electron rich state of cobalt species would suppress the H2 adsorption, facilitate the CO dissociation adsorption and result in a decrease in H/C ratio on Co/Ti–MS catalyst. Consequently, high heavy hydrocarbons selectivity and O/P ratio were observed on Co/Ti–MS catalyst, while increasing H/C ratio with the increasing ZrO2 content led to high methane and light hydrocarbons selectivities over Co/nTiZr–MS catalysts. Comparing with conventional fixed-bed reactors, the slurry-phase reactor presents the advanced technology reactor for FTS reaction. Its advantages include simple construction, excellent heat transfer performance, online catalyst addition and withdrawal, and reasonable interphase mass transfer rates with low energy input, which make it very suitable for FTS reaction. The cobalt-based catalysts for slurry-phase reactor required high mechanic strength to avoid the loss of catalysts owing to the catalyst crushing during re action process. However, it is regretful that the prepared Co/nTiZr–MS catalysts displayed poor mechanic strength. We attempted to evaluate the catalysts performance in slurry-phase reactor and found a quick decrease in CO conversion, which was probably attributed to the loss of catalysts owing to the crushing of catalysts. As seen from the characterization results, the incorporation of promoters (TiO2, ZrO2 and TiO2–ZrO2) into mesoporous silica (MS) would greatly influence the cobalt-support interaction and electron density of cobalt species on Co-based catalysts. Poor dispersion of cobalt species was observed on Co/MS catalysts due to weak Co–SiO2 interaction, which simultaneously caused higher reducibility of cobalt species. However, the incorporation of TiO2 into Co/MS catalyst would suppress cobalt reduction but improve the dispersion cobalt species due to the strengthened Co-support interaction and the blockage of metallic cobalt by the TiO x (x <2) from the partial reduction of TiO2. However, these effects were weakened upon a small addition of ZrO2, which suppressed the migration of TiO x (x <2) species into the surface of metallic cobalt and formation of non-reducible cobalt species, resulting in higher reducibility of cobalt species on Co/3TiZr–MS catalysts. With the further addition of ZrO2, proper dispersion and reducibility of cobalt species were obtained on Co/nTiZr–MS catalysts with high ZrO2 loading. Based on above conclusions, a model of the surface structure of fresh and activated catalysts with different Ti/Zr molar ratios was presented in Fig. 8 . 4 Conclusion The Co-based catalysts containing 10% (wt.%) cobalt supported on mesoporous silica (MS) supports were prepared by impregnation method, moreover TiO2, ZrO2 and binary TiO2–ZrO2 oxides with different Ti/Zr molar ratios of 3:1, 1:1 and 1:3 were imported into catalysts to investigate the effect of promoters on physic-chemical properties and Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS) performance of Co/MS catalyst. The incorporation of TiO2 into Co/MS catalyst could strengthen the interaction between cobalt and support, resulting in higher cobalt dispersion and FTS activity. Meanwhile, lower reduction degree was observed on Co/Ti–MS due to the strengthened Co-support interaction and blockage of cobalt metal by TiO x (x <2), while these effects were suppressed by a small addition of ZrO2. The further addition of ZrO2 increased the reducibility and dispersion of cobalt species, accompanied the increasing catalytic activity of Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS). Moreover, promoters also obviously affected the FTS product distribution. The addition of ZrO2 improved the selectivity to methane and gaseous hydrocarbon products, and restrained the formation of heavy hydrocarbons, while an opposite trend of product selectivity was observed on Co/Ti–MS catalyst. The effect of promoters on FTS product distribution was probably resulted from its influences on H2 and CO adsorption over the surface of Co-based catalysts. The addition of ZrO2 enhanced H2 adsorption but suppressed CO adsorption, which increased the ratios of hydrogen to carbon on the surface of Co-based catalysts, and improved the hydrogenation of surface carbon. However, the electron enrichment of cobalt species on Co/Ti–MS catalyst caused lower H/C ratio, resulting in higher selectivity to heavy hydrocarbons and lower selectivity to methane. coredata.dc:description: A series of Co-based catalysts containing 10wt.% cobalt for Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS) reaction were prepared by impregnation method, in which cobalt species were supported on mesoporous silica (abbreviated as MS) doped with TiO2, ZrO2 and TiO2–ZrO2 oxides as promoters. The incorporation of promoters was observed to have a profound impact on the physic-chemical and catalytic properties of catalysts. It was shown that the dispersion of cobalt species could be improved by the addition of TiO2, resulting in higher catalytic activity on Co/TiO2–MS catalyst (abbreviated as Co/Ti–MS). Meanwhile, the reducibility of cobalt species in Co/Ti–MS was apparently inhabited due to the strong Co–TiO2 interaction, while this effect was suppressed upon a small addition of ZrO2. With the further addition of ZrO2, the reducibility and dispersion of cobalt species were increased simultaneously, resulting in the improved activity. In addition, the H2 chemisorption was enhanced while CO adsorption was suppressed by the incorporation of ZrO2, which increased the H/C ratios on the surface of Co-based catalysts, and promoted the hydrogenation of surface carbon species. Consequently, methane selectivity was enhanced and heavy hydrocarbons selectivity was suppressed in FTS product distribution. The incorporation of promoters into Co/MS catalysts also improved the electron density of cobalt species due to the electron transfer from support to Co via the MOSi structure (M=Ti or Zr). The electron enrichment of cobalt species on Co/Ti–MS catalyst caused lower H/C ratio, resulting in higher selectivity to heavy hydrocarbons and lower selectivity to methane.
coredata.dc:title: Effects of ZrO2 promoter on physic-chemical properties and activity of Co/TiO2–SiO2 Fischer–Tropsch catalysts
